Award.AwardTitle: A Nonlinear Optical Approach to Patchy Particles
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This program, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program, aims to demonstrate a new class of "patchy particles", particles where the surface is patterned with discrete interaction sites that attract or repel complementary sites on other particles - for the purposes of guiding the self-assembly of complex structures with high precision and yield. The technique is optical in nature and relies on the propensity of the plasmonic resonances in metal nanoparticles to concentrate incident light into very small volumes where the electromagnetic field is greatly enhanced. These volumes, known as ?hotspots?, are located at sharp corner or narrow gaps on or between particles. The project will use photoreactive linkers to guide additional particles to bind exclusively at the hotspots so that colloidal molecules can be fabricated in a manner analogous to conventional chemistry, but with nanoparticles instead of atoms. Two simple examples of such structures are a dumbbell shape where two spherical particles are attached to each end of a central rod-shaped particle and a triangular prism where a sphere is attached at each corner. Since the method can be used iteratively, significantly more complex structures, such as branched chains or dendrites, are also possible. Because of the large and rapidly growing variety of silver and gold nanoparticles that can be fabricated, and the numerous types of available photoreactive compounds , this project would represent a significant increase in the number and variety of structures that are feasible within the patchy particle self-assembly paradigm.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
It is now possible to create particles and structures at the nanometer scale with a great deal of variety and precision. The next great challenge is to assemble these building blocks into more complex ordered structures combining different geometries and materials. This project develops an enabling new method using nanoparticles made of silver and gold as the central building blocks. Its success will have implications both for fundamental science and for applied fields such as biomedicine and nanoelectronics, and will therefore help maintain American leadership is these technologically and economically important fields. The project will also help educate the next generation of Ph.D. level workers ready to take leadership positions in interdisciplinary projects at the forefront of science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientists know how to make nanoparticles (particles so small that more than a thousand of them can be laid across the diameter of a human hair) in a great variety of shapes (spheres, rods, triangles, cubes, stars, etc) and materials (metals, semiconductors, insulators). Such particles often have very different properties than either large pieces or individual atoms of the same material. For example, gold nanospheres have a bright red color completely different from the yellow color of bulk god, and semiconductor nanoparticles can fluoresce strongly at visible wavelengths of light, even while the corresponding bulk semiconductor does not.

The next major challange in nanoscience is to assembly nanoparticles into larger, well-ordered structures with predetermined configurations. Such unprecedented control over matter will allow the creation of new materials and devices with completely new properties and functions that be applied to a very wide range of problems. For example, we can expect ultra-light and ultra-strong materials to emerge from this field. New kinds of electronic devices, smaller and faster than current silicon transistor are also a possiblity. In the medical field, well-defined nanoassemblies may be deployed in a large number of roles as for instance biosensors or drug-delivery devices, giving us new diagnosis and treatment options for diseases such as cancer.

The aim of our project is to contribute to this field by taking advantage of a certain optical effect in metal nanoparticles, known as a plasmon resonance, to goad particles to assemble into well-defined construct in a similar manner to the way atoms assemble into molecules. Figure 1 shows schematically the type of structure we hope to achieve. When a metal nanoparticle, typically made of gold or silver, is illuminated by light of the right color, a surface plasmon resonance is created in the particle, which serves to concentrate the light into small patches, known as hot spots, where the intensity of the light can be thousands of times stronger than in the incoming light beam, and tend to occur at sharp corners or inside small gaps in the particles.

We are able to coat metal surfaces with a single layer of a molecule that responds to illumination by cleaving into two pieces, where the piece left behind on the surface of the particle is available to be chemically modified. It is for example possible to make the cleaved molecule obtain a positive electric charge. Since opposite charges attract, this makes it possible to get negatively charged particles to attach to those parts of the surface that were illuminated by light, as in the microscopic image shown in Figure 2.

When a metal nano-particle is coated with this light-cleavable molecule, the strong enhancement of light intensity at the hot spots means that cleaving of the molecule happens much sooner at those location than elsewhere on the particles. Other particles can then be assembled preferentially at the hot spots, which for a gold nanorod occur around the ends of the rod. This process is ilustrated schematically in Figure 3. A microscopic image of a gold nanorod with gold nanospheres assembled at its ends in this manner is shown in Figure 4.

During the award period, we have made several discoveries in this project. The most important ones are:

  1. It is indeed possible to use light to trigger the assembly of nanoparticles in the manner we have hypothesized.
  2. In the case of gold nanorods, we have shown that the attachment can be made preferential to the ends of the rods.
